awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: EAGER: Growing Computer Science Education as a Discipline: Pathways to PhDs
awd_abstract_narration:
Purdue University, in collaboration with SageFox Consulting Group LLC, proposes an exploratory project to study career pathways for PhD students in Computer Science (CS) Education and the support needed to ensure the success of the students. As K-12 schools rapidly adopt new CS curricula, and undergraduate CS enrollments skyrocket, CS Education (CSE) research is increasingly called upon to guide decisions on curricula and pedagogy. To grow CSE as an academic discipline, new collaborations between CS and Education departments are crucial in the preparation of future CSE researchers with respect to courses, graduate programs, mentoring for students and faculty, and joint research efforts. At the institutional level this may be manifested by computer scientists and educators developing new joint degree programs and faculty appointments. At the national level, this may require new forms of infrastructure supportive of those on campuses where critical mass or resources are limited. 

This project aims to identify (1) career pathways and support, training, and mentoring needs for graduate students in CSE research, and (2) academic models that can support graduate students engaged in CSE research, at the institutional and national levels. The effort will start by identifying individuals and programs at academic institutions with active CSE research projects. Based on the feedback and assessment of community surveys and interviews, including CSE graduate students and their advisers, the project will build a Connected Learning Community (CLC) with the goal of connecting, empowering, and mentoring education and computing graduate students. Prototyping the CLC will also serve as a vehicle for better understanding the needs of the CSE graduate students and developing new pathways to support them.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
The growth in demand for equitable high quality computing education is evident world-wide. The future leaders that will potentially support this growth are currently graduate students and post-docs spread across an array of programs in computer science, education and social sciences; often working in relative isolation from mainstream programs in their home institution or as part of connected communities. The core questions for this project were to understand the academic and career pathways available to computer science education (CSEd) research PhD students and what support mechanisms exist/should exist to support them.

The initial phase of the project was to identify and engage CSEd graduate students and advisors. Remarkably, 332 graduate students, post-docs and advisors representing 106 higher education institutions from 54 different countries became registered participants in the emergent learning community.

With disruption due to Covid 19, this project shifted into a virtual mode for both the community-based activities and the research. The community activities were highlighted by a student-led virtual conference that engaged students with numerous authors of the The Cambridge Handbook of Computing Education Research. The experience demonstrated the value of cross discipline engagement among leading and emerging researchers in a field where students have difficulty accessing experts and foundational training in a discipline outside their own. This was evident in discussion of learning science theories, models of how students learn core computing concepts, and the social science associated with defining and implementing equitable education systems.

Another shift was to redesign the research approach away from being led and conducted by the proposed PI and co-PI team to one engaging graduate students in addressing the project?s questions focused on: where is CSEd research was happening, how are graduate students engaged, and what support is needed to advance their careers. The results (presented in six publications and four conference posters) were threefold: better understanding of the CSEd graduate students? experience, needs and challenges; the anticipated value of creating a Research Experience for Graduate Students (REG); and a remarkable set of personal outcomes for both the mentoring team and the engaged graduate students.

CSEd Graduate students are highly motivated to take on the challenges of understanding and implementing equitable computer science education from pre-K through graduate programs. Their entry into the field and finding a supportive opportunity is often serendipitous given the scarcity of dedicated programs. A key finding of this project was recognizing the value of a supportive community to provide learning opportunities, expert and peer mentoring, research opportunities, and professional networking.

The pandemic isolated everyone, including graduate students and their adviser, researchers and their peers. Our project invited graduate students and post-docs to get engaged in a new environment parallel to the research with their adviser. It empowered graduate students and post-docs. It provided an outlet for activities that the adviser may not have supported and it allowed building a new network, without the judgment of an adviser. For many participants, the activities built confidence, allowed new collaborations and engagement, and provided new perspectives and feedback. Our success in actively engaging graduate students was done in response to the necessary shift and refocusing of activities due to COVID.  When it started, it was hard to predict how it would work. It ended up being very successful and might be worth exploring further through the creation of a Research Experience for Graduate Students program.

 

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 12/27/2022
Modified by: Susanne E Hambrusch
